channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Warning Ukraine’s Friends to ‘Think Twice,’ Putin Tests Advanced Missile
item.description: Russia’s Defense Ministry said the weapon needed more testing before it could be deployed. Ukrainian officials said they were pushing back at Moscow’s offensive in the east.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of the village of Avdiivka, along the front line in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, during a Russian bombardment on Wednesday.

item.title: He Was a Penniless Donor to the Far Right. He Was Also a Russian Spy.
item.description: An investigation in Slovakia has exposed how Russian clandestine operations are trying to sow discord in Europe and create sympathy for Moscow over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city center in Kosice, Slovakia. The Kremlin has sought to win influence and sow discord on Europe’s formerly communist eastern fringe.

item.title: Deep in Colombia, Rebels and Soldiers Fight for the Same Prize: Drugs
item.description: The country signed a historic peace deal more than five years ago. But a power vacuum is fueling the rise of new armed groups competing to control the drug trade.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Members of the Comandos de la Frontera militia during training in the south of Colombia.

item.title: Housing Crisis Propels High Death Toll in South Africa Floods
item.description: The catastrophe underscored an overlooked reality in the fight against extreme weather: Protecting people is as much about tackling social issues as environmental ones.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Zanele Mji and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The edge of a destroyed bridge in Inanda, north of Durban, on Monday, after weeks of flooding in Kwazulu-Natal Province, South Africa.

item.title: How Hated Is Macron? It Could Decide the French Election.
item.description: Given the choice between a president they suspect of despising ordinary people and a far-right candidate they detest, many French voters may stay home.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France visited a wind-turbine factory in Le Havre during a campaign stop before the final round of the French presidential elections on Sunday.

item.title: The U.S. Races to Arm Ukraine With Heavier, More Advanced Weaponry
item.description: Washington and its allies are scouring Central Europe and the world to get Ukraine the weapons it needs for the next phase of the war.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Ukrainian service members unpacking Javelin anti-tank missiles in Kyiv in February. The missiles were part of the U.S. military support package.

item.title: Why China’s Security Pact With the Solomon Islands is a Threat
item.description: In potentially opening the door to a Chinese military base, the Solomon Islands threatens the balance of power in a vital shipping region.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: The Solomon Islands’ prime minister, Manasseh Sogavare, with the Chinese premier, Li Keqiang, in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: 6 Rohingya Refugees Are Killed Fleeing Detention Center in Malaysia
item.description: In recent years, the Malaysian government has taken a more hard-line approach to the refugees in the country, which once offered a modicum of opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: A total of 528 detainees escaped from a detention center in the northern state of Penang after “riots” occurred around 4 a.m., according to officials.

item.title: Shanghai’s Low Covid Death Toll Revives Questions About China’s Numbers
item.description: The country’s largest city has recorded just 17 Covid deaths, despite surging cases. How China defines a Covid death may be part of the reason.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang, Joy Dong and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Medical staff members arriving with a patient at the Wuhan Red Cross Hospital in January 2020.

item.title: U.K. Court Order Moves Assange Closer to Extradition
item.description: The court formally ordered the extradition of the WikiLeaks founder to the United States, but it still needs approval from a British cabinet minister and his defense can appeal to her directly.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange on the balcony of the Embassy of Ecuador in London, in 2017. He sought refuge there for seven years.

item.title: Prince Harry Puts Noses Out of Joint With Comments About the Queen
item.description: The prince, in Europe for the Invictus Games, visited his grandmother then told the “Today” show that he wanted to make sure “she’s protected.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth appeared via video from Windsor Castle to receive the Democratic Republic of Congo's Ambassador to the United Kingdom, Pascal Gayma, this month. He was at Buckingham Palace.

item.title: Star Ferry, ‘Emblem of Hong Kong,’ May Sail Into History After 142 Years
item.description: Launched in 1880, the ferry has witnessed both Hong Kong’s transformation into a global financial hub and its history of protests. But battered by a pandemic, the service is struggling to survive.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers riding on a Star Ferry, offering spectacular views of the harbor in Hong Kong.

item.title: Johnson Is All Apologies Before Parliament After ‘Partygate’ Fine
item.description: Though opposition politicians called him out, only one member of his own Conservative party called on him to resign.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson departing 10 Downing Street on Tuesday in London.

item.title: Macron and Le Pen Trade Punches in Pivotal French Election Debate
item.description: He attacked the far-right leader as a Putin stooge. She hit back at him as the president of division and contempt.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People at a Paris bar watching the live televised presidential debate between Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen on Wednesday.

item.title: See Mariupol’s Azovstal Steel-Mill Fortress Before the War, and Now
item.description: Before-and-after images show the scale of destruction that the Ukrainian port city has suffered after nearly two months of near constant bombardment by Russian artillery, mortars and airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald

item.title: Russia Tests ICBM and Pounds Ukraine’s Defenses Ahead of Major Assault
item.description: Vladimir Putin said Russia’s test-firing of its new I.C.B.M. sends a message, as his forces prepare for a broad offensive in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matviy, 12, lying in a basement shelter decorated with a graffiti-style mural in the village of Avdiivka, along the frontline with Russian troops in the Donetsk region of Eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia’s Missile Test Fuels U.S. Fears of an Isolated Putin
item.description: American and foreign leaders have been weighing whether their success in making Russia a diplomatic pariah could push President Vladimir V. Putin to strike in new ways.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: American officials have encountered repeated reminders by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that the world is messing with a nuclear weapons power and should tread carefully.

item.title: What Mariupol’s Steel Fortress Looked Like 3 Months Ago
item.description: On Jan. 20, The New York Times captured drone video over the sprawling Azovstal Steel and Iron works complex in Mariupol, Ukraine. Now, it is a battered fortress for the last Ukrainian defenders and their families battling Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald

item.title: People Should Keep Wearing Masks in Public, W.H.O. Officials Say
item.description: Masks have been proven to be highly effective at reducing coronavirus transmission when used properly, according to the W.H.O.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grand Central Station in Manhattan. World Health Organization officials encouraged people to wear masks in indoor public places and outdoors where social distancing is not possible.

item.title: Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, 95, Dies; Fought for Mexico’s ‘Disappeared’
item.description: When her son vanished in 1975, she began a crusade on behalf of him and hundreds of others and became a voice of moral authority on the left.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Threatens Escalation
item.description: Plus the emergence of armed militias in Colombia and questions over China’s Covid death toll.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maxim and Tanya Khomenko, with the help of their relatives, moved their belongings from their destroyed apartment building in Horenka, northwest of Kyiv, Ukraine.Credit...

item.title: Residents in Avdiivka, Ukraine Go Underground as Russia’s Assault on East Ramps Up
item.description: As Ukrainian forces dig into trenches and residents flee into basements, Russia’s artillery attacks have intensified. “They can’t get through the front lines and so they’re starting simply to destroy the city,” a Ukrainian official said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Like many other residents of Avdiivka, Ukraine, Matviy, 12, has sought shelter from Russian bombardment in a basement. The village has come under increasing artillery fire as Russia shifts its offensive to Ukraine’s east.

item.title: Barack Obama’s New Role: Fighting Disinformation
item.description: The former president has embarked on a campaign to warn that the scourge of online falsehoods has eroded the foundations of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Cecilia Kang
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama has waded deeply into the public fray over misinformation and disinformation.

item.title: Calls to Give Heavy Weapons to Ukraine Divide Germany’s Government
item.description: Weeks after Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a paradigm shift in military strategy, his government is struggling to balance domestic politics, how to help Ukraine and anxiety over provoking Russia. that
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Under Chancellor Olaf Scholz and prompted by the war in Ukraine, Germany has turned away from its decades of pacifist policy and toward rearming itself and supplying arms for Ukrainian soldiers.

item.title: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen walked out of a G20 meeting as Russia’s finance minister spoke.
item.description: Several central bank governors and finance ministers protested Russia’s participation at the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Russia Said It Has Successfully Tested a New ICBM That Can Evade Defenses
item.description: Though officials said the missile is not yet ready to deploy, President Vladimir V. Putin said the launch of the Sarmat missile “will force all who are trying to threaten our country in the heat of frenzied, aggressive rhetoric to think twice.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Russian Defence Ministry
item.media:description: A Sarmat intercontinental ballistic missile was launched by Russia on Wednesday, as seen on this screengrab from video footage released by the Russian Defense Ministry.

item.title: Why ‘Border Control’ Politics Is More About Control Than Borders
item.description: A quirk of political psychology helps explain the British government’s plan to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrating outside Britain’s Parliament in January against a previously proposed immigration bill.

item.title: Myanmar faces a health emergency as its military regime targets doctors.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:description: Patients with gunshot wounds in an emergency ward last March in Yangon, Myanmar. The staff had shut down the hospital as part of mass protests against the military coup weeks earlier, but were secretly treating injured protestors.

item.title: Can Ukraine Keep Winning?
item.description: As a new phase of the war begins, we look at Russia’s advantages — and Ukraine’s.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A bombed neighborhood in Kharkiv, Ukraine yesterday.

item.title: Ukrainians Far From Home Struggle to Protect Family With Dementia
item.description: Millions of Ukrainians have been displaced since the war started. Many elderly or disabled people have been unable or unwilling to leave their homes.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many elderly Ukrainians with dementia have woken up to a new war, day after day.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s offensive in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A local resident in front of a destroyed apartment building in the southern port city of Mariupol, Ukraine on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Rejects Calls for a Cease-Fire to Enable Evacuations From Ukraine
item.description: Civilians, including children, remain trapped in the eastern Ukraine region of Donbas and in the devastated port city of Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Dmitry Polyanskiy, a deputy Russian ambassador to the United Nations, rejected calls for a cease-fire in Ukraine at a meeting of the U.N. Security Council on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Embarks on a New, More Cautious Phase of Ukraine War
item.description: Despite the Kremlin’s new methodical approach focusing on eastern Ukraine, the Russian military still faces some of the same problems that hampered it after the war began.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Rogachov Vladimir Petrovich at the scene of one of the areas bombed Tuesday in the Saltivka neighborhood of Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Bombards the East
item.description: Moscow’s military offensive in eastern Ukraine has begun.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A strike in a residential neighborhood of Kharkiv on Tuesday killed at least three people.

item.title: Biden Says It’s ‘Up to Them’ Whether Americans Want to Wear Masks
item.description: The decision to wear a mask is “up to them,” President Biden told reporters during a trip.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport in Atlanta on Tuesday. The White House is encouraging Americans to continue to wear masks on public transportation.

item.title: Huge Steel Plant in Mariupol Is a Fortress for Ukrainian Holdouts
item.description: A huge Soviet-era steel mill is where the last Ukrainian defenders of Mariupol have taken refuge as Russia’s battle to take full control of the city appeared to be entering its final stages.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Cora Engelbrecht and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Smoke rose over the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol on Monday. The plant, where Ukrainian defenders are holding out, is a four-square-mile complex with a network of underground spaces.

item.title: Inside ‘The Burnt City,’ Punchdrunk’s Take on the Fall of Troy
item.description: Punchdrunk’s “The Burnt City” adds techno and sake to the story of the fall of Troy, but it brought in a scholar of classical theater to get the details right.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emma Cole, center, a historical consultant for “The Burnt City,” with Maxine Doyle and Felix Barrett of Punchdrunk. Cole said Punchdrunk’s innovation had “the exact same spirit” as Greek tragedians.

item.title: Letizia Battaglia, Photographer of Mafia Brutality, Dies at 87
item.description: Her images of victims on the streets of Palermo were stamped on the nation’s consciousness as she challenged the grip mobsters had on her native Sicily.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ms. Battaglia at her home in 2017. “I never thought of myself as an artist,” she said, “and I am still astonished to enter into a museum and see my work.”

item.title: Here’s how to handle some of the most irritating workplace habits when you return to the office.
item.dc:creator: Jancee Dunn

item.title: In French Election, Cartoonists Play a High-Profile Role
item.description: Cartoonists play a high-profile role in France’s political discourse, and they have been busy drawing the presidential candidates as the race approaches its end.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon

item.title: Afghanistan School Explosions: At Least 6 Dead in Kabul
item.description: More than a dozen people were also wounded, one as young as 7. The attacks again challenged the Taliban’s promise of security, and stoked deep-seated fears in the Shiite community.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Yaqoob Akbary
item.media:description: Taliban fighters stand guard at the site of an explosion in front of a school in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: How Memes Are Driving Ukraine’s Fundraising Efforts
item.description: A campaign using internet memes and merchandise has rallied international public support for Ukraine in its war with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: T-shirts and stickers featuring the Virgin Mary holding an antitank missile are being sold to help fund Ukrainian aid organizations.

item.title: The W.H.O. chief arrives in India, amid a tussle over Covid death estimates.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Salvatore Di Nolfi/Keystone, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the director general of the World Health Organization, inaugurated an international center for traditional medicine in western India on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Restores Climate to Environmental Law, Reversing Trump
item.description: A new rule requires agencies to analyze the climate impacts of proposed highways, pipelines and other projects, and gives local communities more input.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Biden administration plans to resurrect requirements of the 50-year-old National Environmental Policy Act that had been removed by President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: World Economic Outlook Dims as War and Pandemic Cast a Pall
item.description: The International Monetary Fund’s new World Economic Outlook expects growth to slow to 3.6 percent this year. The group is one of many to slash their forecasts recently.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees waited to sign up for temporary residence permits in Brussels. The war in Ukraine is among the overlapping crises dimming expectations for the global economy this year.

item.title: Russia’s Thrust in Eastern Ukraine Combines Firepower and New Caution
item.description: The military campaign that Moscow said it had now begun appears much more methodical than those it pursued in the war’s first days
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: An artillery strike on Monday killed at least one person and wounded another in a residential area in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: ‘Big Screaming Headlines’
item.description: Coronavirus cases have risen in major cities. Hospitalizations have not.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Covid-19 testing site in Brooklyn yesterday.

item.title: China’s Covid Shutdowns Go Far Beyond Shanghai
item.description: Cities and towns across the country are shutting down, hoping to sidestep the pitfalls and stumbles that Shanghai has faced battling the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Testing for the virus in Shanghai on Tuesday. The city of Wuhu in Anhui Province is entering a similar lockdown after reporting two Covid cases.

item.title: A Mask Mandate Ends Midflight, Sparking Cheers and Alarm
item.description: Airport terminals and flights erupted in applause, while some passengers said the abrupt policy change put them at risk.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Brittany Murray/MediaNews Group/Long Beach Press-Telegram, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Travelers at Los Angeles International Airport on Monday. The T.S.A. announced that it would stop enforcing its mask mandate after a federal judge in Florida struck down the requirement.

item.title: A Door-to-Door Effort to Find Out Who Died Helps Low-Income Countries Aid the Living
item.description: Many developing countries don’t keep official death records. A novel effort uses “electronic autopsies” to count deaths, and record their cause.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: In northern Sierra Leone, Isata Kaitongi, top right, interviewed people in the village of Mabin to gather cause-of-death statistics.

item.title: Myanmar’s Health System Is in Collapse, ‘Obliterated’ by the Regime
item.description: The country is also now one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a medical worker. At least 30 doctors have been killed since the coup, a rights group says.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Patients with gunshot wounds in an emergency ward last March in Yangon, Myanmar. The staff had shut down the hospital as part of mass protests against the military coup weeks earlier, but were secretly treating injured protestors.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Onlookers at the scene of a missile strike that hit a tire fitting plant in Lviv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Which U.S. Airlines Dropped Their Mask Mandate
item.description: After a federal mandate was struck down, major carriers said masks would be optional on domestic flights.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: Most large U.S. airlines, including American, JetBlue and United, said passengers and crew would no longer be required to wear masks on domestic flights.

item.title: U.N. Official Said He Tested Positive for Covid After In-Person Meeting
item.description: One meeting had included the U.N.’s secretary general, but everyone in the room was wearing masks, a spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Martin Griffiths briefs reporters on the humanitarian situation in Ukraine at United Nations headquarters in New York on Monday. He tested positive for the coronavirus later in the day.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russia Begins Assault in the East After Raining Missiles Nationwide
item.description: The president of Ukraine and a top national security aide said the Russian offensive, anticipated for weeks, had finally begun after a Russian missile barrage that included the first deadly strike on the western city of Lviv.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf, Ivan Nechepurenko and Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters struggle to extinguish a blaze from a missile strike Monday on a tire-fitting plant in Lviv in western Ukraine. At least seven people were killed in missile strikes on the city.

item.title: New Rocket Fire From Gaza Follows Rising Tensions in Israel
item.description: The first strike from Gaza in several months came just days after clashes in and around the Aqsa Mosque compound, a sacred site for both Muslims and Jews.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel’s Iron Dome anti-missile system launching to intercept rockets fired from the Gaza Strip during the war last year.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Launches Assault in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Plus China’s lockdowns slow its economy and France’s candidates vie for undecided voters.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
